questions.questionText: How does the process of making a Git commit differ when working in pairs, versus when working independently?
What is the significance of the word 'master' in the command $ git push al master?
What is the difference between the local .git repository, and the repository created on Github?
How are the local .git repository, and the repository created on Github 'connected'?
What does it mean that web development can be behavior-driven?
What is represented in a specification?
What is the purpose of refactoring? Why is refactoring ideally completed before moving on to the next specification?
What is a key-value pair? What does a key represent? How about the value?
When might we use a hash? What's the difference between a Hash and an Array?
How does inheritance work in Ruby? How is it useful?
What is the difference between a module and a class?
When should we use a mixin instead of class inheritance?
What is an attr method and why are these methods useful?
What is the Enumerable module and what are some of its most useful methods? (Take some time to look over the Enumerable documentation if you havenâ€™t already.)
What is the difference between map() and an each() loop?
What is a GET request?
What is an embedded Ruby tag?
How is the form action in a form important to a Sinatra application?
How does Sinatra know which route to execute?
Describe how app.rb routes are used to manage data between models (classes and methods) and views (.erb files).
What is the difference between GET and POST requests?
What is an integration test?
What is Capybara?
What is the difference between a class variable and an instance variable?
Why would you create a class method instead of an instance method?
Why should you generally avoid class variables?
What is dynamic routing and why is it useful?
What is namespacing? How can we use modules to namespace classes?
How do we look up constants in Ruby?
What does it mean when there is a colon in a Sinatra app.rb route? (ie: get('/users/:id') do)? What does the :id portion of the route represent?
What is the difference between local, instance, class and global variables? This may be review, but at this point, the differences should be very clear!
In BDD, why is it important to begin by testing the simplest possible behavior?
Why should we write tests for our code? What can happen if we do not?
What is the initialize() method? What is it responsible for? When does it run?
What is the difference between a local and instance variable? What about an instance variable and a class variable?
What is a class? What benefits do they offer?
What is an object?
What is a module and why should we use them?
What is a class method? When should we define a class method instead of an instance method?
What is the difference between a GET and POST request? Provide an example use case of each.
Why is a primary key important for database records?
What is the difference between a primary key and a foreign key?
What has to be done to make two tables become related in a database?
What is the difference between a one-to-one, one-to-many, and many-to-many database relationship?
Come up with an example use case for each of the three database relationships listed in the previous question.
When would we use a hidden form field? What functionality would this offer?
What is the difference between a PATCH and POST request?
What is the purpose of RESTful routing? What benefit does it offer?
What special value, type and name must be added to a form in order to successfully execute a DELETE request in Sinatra?
Why do we execute many-to-many relationships with a join table?
When might we use a join statement? Why?
What is the difference between postgres and psql? What is each responsible for? How does a developer interact with each?
What does the term relational database mean? How does a relational database structure its data?
What is the difference between a primary key and a foreign key? What is each used for?
How can we locate a specific object or database entry in an SQL database? What does this SQL query look like? Construct one using a whiteboard, scratch paper, or directly in an Atom text editor.
Why is it important that the ID value of objects in our application match the ID of that information's entry in our database?
How can we ensure the ID value of objects in our application match the ID of that information's entry in our database?
In a one-to-many relationship, how do we associate a new object with its parent object in the database?
Walk through each of the following types of HTTP requests, describe what they do, and when you would use each: PATCH, POST, GET, DELETE
Walk through each of the following types of standard database relationships, describe what they do, and when you would use each: One-to-One, One-to-Many, Many-to-Many
In a one-to-many relationship, why does the 'many' contain the ID value of the 'one' it belongs to? Why not the other way around? What do you think?
What is a migration? What can be accomplished with migrations? What can't be?
How do we configure our application to use Active Record?
How do we instruct one class to inherit from another? What benefit does this offer?
What is rake?
What is the difference between a validation and a callback?
When would you use a validation? What benefit does it offer?
When would you use a callback? What benefit do they offer?
When might we use a redirect in Sinatra? How does this differ from other methods of navigation?
What is the difference between declaring a has_and_belongs_to_many relationship, and a has_many :through relationship? Come up with an example use case for each.
How can we delete an entry from a join table using Active Record? What does this code look like?
What is C#? What is .NET Core 1.1?
Review the data types in C# with your pair. What are they, and how are they different?
How are classes declared? What are the benefits of using classes?
What is encapsulation and why is it important?
What are namespaces?
What is MS Test? What is a testing framework?
What process should we follow when designing our specs?
Why should we use plain-English specs when we begin our specs?
Explain the process of turning a spec into a test.
Why is the 'red-green-refactor' method so important to behavior-driven development?
What does it mean when we say interfaces before implementation? Why do we say that?
What is a static property? How do we use it?
When would we use an instance method instead of a static method?

What does it mean when we state that a program threw an exception'? What occurs when this happens?

What is a stack trace? What would a developer use one for?
Discuss the benefits of testing. Why should we write tests for our code? What can happen if we do not?
What do the terms arrange, act and assert mean, in terms of testing?
Pretend you've encountered a bug in your MVC application. What steps would you go through to attempt debugging it? In what order would you try each?

What is Razor, and how is it designed to save us time?

Can you explain the HTTP process? Define the terms post and get.
Describe a Find() method. Why might we write one, and what are the uses of this method?

What does CRUD stand for?
What is the difference between a PATCH and POST request?
What is the purpose of RESTful routing? What benefit does it offer?
Discuss the difference between POST and GET. When do we use a POST route, when a GET?

Walk through each of the following types of standard database relationships, describe what they do, and when you would use each: One-to-One, One-to-Many, Many-to-Many

What are you looking forward to learning most?

What are some real-life examples of many-to-many relationships?
Make a schema of some of these relationships using the SQL Designer. How is a join table used to create a relationship between two tables?
What changes were made to turn the to do list into a many-to-many relationship between items and categories?

How is the query from a join statement returned? How do join statements make our lives easier?

How do join statements make our lives easier?

hat is a join statement? Is it related to a join table? Why or why not?

How does a dynamic route fill its dynamic segment?

What is fat arrow notation? How does it affect scope? And the keyword this? Why is this functionality beneficial?

Describe the process by which components pass actions upwards to one another? Again, what tools need to be in place to do this?
How do we decide when to make a new component?
What are services used for? Where can we place them? Do they have to pass data down, and actions up too?

Now, describe how Angular fits the MVC (model-view-controller/component) design pattern.
